summary:
Girl I-
Fuck it looks like it'd be dark beer which I usually hate, but if you think I won't make an exception and buy a shit ton...
body:
Girl I-

Fuck it looks like it’d be dark beer which I usually hate, but if you think I won’t make an exception and buy a shit ton of this and get wasted, you’re wrong

Now I need a Cersei wine (and sth Dany themed so I can get drunk on Jonerys)

blog.name: tluohsalohcin
blog.title: Justice for Jon Snow and Jaime Lannister
blog.description: Official member of the Sansa Stark Defense Squad. Certified Jonsa Trash. Also a Nick Hoult loyalist since 2011.

summary:
My opinions when I watched S1 for the first time VS My opinions when I watched S1 recently for the second time
Jon Snow...
body:
My opinions when I watched S1 for the first time VS My opinions when I watched S1 recently for the second time

Jon Snow *perverted face* / Damn, he’s still a boy, bit naive, but with courage.

Joffrey can go fuck himself / Actually Cersei and even Robert spoiled him since very early years with the thought he can do whatever he wants when he becomes king, and ignored the early signs.

Robb is badass / Damn Robb boy, you swallowed your fear, you were doing just right and trying your best, ily.

Jaime is an asshole / We got from Jaime very early signs of a good heart, but we dismissed it.

Poor thing Daenerys / No matter what difficult life she got, she still manages to do her will no matter what and even if it is questionable. Also what kind of Stockholm Syndrome was that? Also puts a lot of value of she as kind of a sexual object. How did I dismissed it?

Tyrion is cynical / Still a cynical but spoiled man dragging about his fathers money in almost every situation.

Cersei is power hungry / Still a power hungry, but with some sense, she wasn’t conviced that killing Ned was the best thing, but still didn’t mind after all.

Poor babe Sansa / And still did nothing wrong, just tried to save her father and Joffrey betrayed her.

You good out there with weapons, Arya / I like her, but now I find her overrated.

summary: You’ve talked a lot about how the timelines don’t work for Ned to explain Jon away as either Benjen’s or Brandon’s bastard. I’m...
question: You’ve talked a lot about how the timelines don’t work for Ned to explain Jon away as either Benjen’s or Brandon’s bastard. I’m trying to wrap my head around why the timeline DOES work for Ned himself. Catelyn thinks at one point Ashara Dayne is Jon’s mother, but surely  Ned was nowhere near Dorne and Ashara nine months before Jon was born? The “Wylla” story seems to suffer from the same problem. Or did Ned spend a lot of time crisscrossing Westeros like a pinball during the war?
answer:
Ned did indeed pinball around Westeros during Robert’s Rebellion, inasmuch as people can pinball around a continent without the aid of motorised transport. He started in the Eyrie, went back to Winterfell via the Fingers and White Harbour, marched south to Riverrun and then to Stoney Sept, fought at the Trident, dashed to King’s Landing, from there went to Storm’s End, and finally headed to Dorne. He spent a lot of time on the move, in busy camps, with lots of people coming and going around him. 

Unlike Brandon, accounted for in his grave, and Benjen, accounted for at Winterfell (and also barely old enough to be messing around with girls anyway), Ned had plenty of opportunity for a discreet quickie. With Ned refusing to name Jon’s mother, it’s not like anyone could check the details of his story.

summary: Daenerys and Jon by Spring-Fairy on DeviantArt
caption: Daenerys and Jon by Spring-Fairy on DeviantArt

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: Jon Snow by Alejandro Rubio Ramos
caption: Jon Snow by Alejandro Rubio Ramos

title: The Case for Drogo
body:
Yesterday, I got a really awesome review for a chapter in ‘Eye of the Storm’  - where Jon and Drogo come to terms with each other. Basically the review (as well as the many others I received then) stated how I made them think differently of the khal. And as a writer, that’s one of the greatest compliments one can receive.

In my opinion, GRRM made him almost too two-dimensional. Yes, he’s from a race of brutes and raped Dany (unforgivable), he pillages and allows his people to do reprehensible things, but I’ve always thought there should have been more to him than meets the eye. So how does one take a character like Drogo - supposed to be hated and despised - and turn him into a somewhat sympathetic character without losing what makes him so fearsome to his people/or as a character?

It wasn’t easy, and I had to do a couple of outlines/re-writes/mucho-thinking, but this section I highlight was the basic gist of his development as a character, and though I find it hard to love most of what I write, I really enjoyed this section (even as a ‘reader’) *lol*

“You touch by maegi? Yes?”

“Uumm-”

“A sorceress,” Jorah explained. “He thinks you might have been touched by…someone like that. I guess I could tell him otherwise…”

“No,” Jon interrupted as he held Drogo’s gaze. “He’s right. A woman did heal me. I don’t know if she was a magician or witch or whatever, but…these scars…they healed much faster after she touched me.”

“Does Dany know this?” Jorah asked sharply.

“Not yet,” Jon confessed. “I’ll tell her in time.”

Drogo grinned at his deduction and nodded. “I feel it in you. We are same. Touch by maegi when I was khalakka, but not easy. No. Not easy, Snow. All this…” He spread out his arms. “The gods give me all, but my enemies plenty. Everywhere. Many want me dead, even in my khas, so I must be careful. Yes?”

Jon nodded; hoping his expression gave nothing away. Why was Drogo telling him all this? It wasn’t as if he was hoping Jon would feel sorry for him, was it? This was the life he had chosen for himself after all. However, a part of him had to sympathize. From what he had seen of those who were made to lead, that phrase of ‘keeping one’s enemies close’ was never truer. It wasn’t hard to imagine Drogo having so many eager for his head. Hell, hadn’t he felt the same way just a few days ago?

“My people no change easy,” Drogo continued. “They must have strong khal, one to keep them together or they destroy even more. You understand?”

“…yes…but…you are the khal, right? You do have the power to make changes if you wished,” Jon began cautiously. At Drogo’s raised brow, Jon forced himself to continue; hoping his words wouldn’t come out the wrong way. “I know it’s not easy to rule such a people, but as the khal of the greatest khalasar, you can show that there’s more to life than pillaging and raping your women and slaves…hell even that concept is revolting in itself. No offense, Your Grace, but I think you really should reconsider continuing that practice.”

His words died off, and as he waited for Jorah to interpret for it appeared as if Drogo did not completely understand what he was trying to say, Jon held his breath and waited for the admonishment or fury for his speech. Who was he to tell Drogo what to do anyway?

There was a tense silence as Drogo digested this new information, and he seemed to study Jon as one would study a unique specimen beneath a microscope.

“To be khal is like…atthirarido…a big dream for rider,” he finally said; his voice still contemplative. He waved his hand toward the direction of his khas. They looked like shimmering mirages from this distance.  “But to be khal is to wake with sun and wonder if it be your last to see it. And Dan Ares, she know this, and she want to take chair of Westeros. She know it not easy, but I promise her that…and she leave me…”

His features tightened with mingled expressions of pain and anger. He seemed to grow weary of speaking in the Common Tongue and resorted to finishing his speech in Dothraki; pausing only long enough for Jorah to interpret.

“He says it was humiliating to accept her escape and had to appease his angry bloodriders who wanted to go after her head. It was one of the reasons he chose to work with the fat man…Robert Baratheon I’m guessing…when he proposed that they join forces to conquer Westeros and stop Daenerys’s quest. He was only doing it to punish her in kind, for there were many nights he had spent dreaming of her, wondering if she was even still alive and hoping she had made it safe and sound. Perhaps they might have even ruled Westeros together; despite how cursed the Narrow Sea is to his people. He was willing to make that sacrifice.”

When Jorah stopped, Drogo spoke some more and even Jorah seemed to have a bemused yet astonished expression on his visage. Jon was just as flummoxed at this rush of verbal diarrhea. It almost felt as if the khal was desperate to let this burden off him and had finally been given an opportunity to do so.

“He says he knows what a risk it was for Dany to come back and he admires her for it, but a part of him is still angry that she came with you. He wants to punish you both for daring to show your affections for one another in his presence and humiliating him before his khalasar, but he would hate to see the pain in Dany’s eyes if he killed you, which he can do easily if he so chooses. So he is going to make you an offer…since you won the horse race, you will decide what to do with Haggo. The best choice would be to engage him in another duel, but this time, it will be a duel to the death.”

Jon’s breath caught; his eyes widening in disbelief.

“If you are able to defeat him, then he will be willing to give up Dany as well as his quest to conquer Westeros. You still have to prove to be worthy of being her khal, and who knows? You might even end up leaving Vaes Dothrak with your personal khalasar.”

“My people no change easy,” Drogo continued. “They must have strong khal, one to keep them together or they destroy even more. You understand?”

“…yes…but…you are the khal, right? You do have the power to make changes if you wished,” Jon began cautiously. At Drogo’s raised brow, Jon forced himself to continue; hoping his words wouldn’t come out the wrong way. “I know it’s not easy to rule such a people, but as the khal of the greatest khalasar, you can show that there’s more to life than pillaging and raping your women and slaves…hell even that concept is revolting in itself. No offense, Your Grace, but I think you really should reconsider continuing that practice.”

His words died off, and as he waited for Jorah to interpret for it appeared as if Drogo did not completely understand what he was trying to say, Jon held his breath and waited for the admonishment or fury for his speech. Who was he to tell Drogo what to do anyway?

reblog.comment:
Yesterday, I got a really awesome review for a chapter in ‘Eye of the Storm’  - where Jon and Drogo come to terms with each other. Basically the review (as well as the many others I received then) stated how I made them think differently of the khal. And as a writer, that’s one of the greatest compliments one can receive.

In my opinion, GRRM made him almost too two-dimensional. Yes, he’s from a race of brutes and raped Dany (unforgivable), he pillages and allows his people to do reprehensible things, but I’ve always thought there should have been more to him than meets the eye. So how does one take a character like Drogo - supposed to be hated and despised - and turn him into a somewhat sympathetic character without losing what makes him so fearsome to his people/or as a character?

It wasn’t easy, and I had to do a couple of outlines/re-writes/mucho-thinking, but this section I highlight was the basic gist of his development as a character, and though I find it hard to love most of what I write, I really enjoyed this section (even as a ‘reader’) *lol*

“You touch by maegi? Yes?”

“Uumm-”

“A sorceress,” Jorah explained. “He thinks you might have been touched by…someone like that. I guess I could tell him otherwise…”

“No,” Jon interrupted as he held Drogo’s gaze. “He’s right. A woman did heal me. I don’t know if she was a magician or witch or whatever, but…these scars…they healed much faster after she touched me.”

“Does Dany know this?” Jorah asked sharply.

“Not yet,” Jon confessed. “I’ll tell her in time.”

Drogo grinned at his deduction and nodded. “I feel it in you. We are same. Touch by maegi when I was khalakka, but not easy. No. Not easy, Snow. All this…” He spread out his arms. “The gods give me all, but my enemies plenty. Everywhere. Many want me dead, even in my khas, so I must be careful. Yes?”

Jon nodded; hoping his expression gave nothing away. Why was Drogo telling him all this? It wasn’t as if he was hoping Jon would feel sorry for him, was it? This was the life he had chosen for himself after all. However, a part of him had to sympathize. From what he had seen of those who were made to lead, that phrase of ‘keeping one’s enemies close’ was never truer. It wasn’t hard to imagine Drogo having so many eager for his head. Hell, hadn’t he felt the same way just a few days ago?

“My people no change easy,” Drogo continued. “They must have strong khal, one to keep them together or they destroy even more. You understand?”

“…yes…but…you are the khal, right? You do have the power to make changes if you wished,” Jon began cautiously. At Drogo’s raised brow, Jon forced himself to continue; hoping his words wouldn’t come out the wrong way. “I know it’s not easy to rule such a people, but as the khal of the greatest khalasar, you can show that there’s more to life than pillaging and raping your women and slaves…hell even that concept is revolting in itself. No offense, Your Grace, but I think you really should reconsider continuing that practice.”

His words died off, and as he waited for Jorah to interpret for it appeared as if Drogo did not completely understand what he was trying to say, Jon held his breath and waited for the admonishment or fury for his speech. Who was he to tell Drogo what to do anyway?

[[MORE]]

There was a tense silence as Drogo digested this new information, and he seemed to study Jon as one would study a unique specimen beneath a microscope.

“To be khal is like…atthirarido…a big dream for rider,” he finally said; his voice still contemplative. He waved his hand toward the direction of his khas. They looked like shimmering mirages from this distance.  “But to be khal is to wake with sun and wonder if it be your last to see it. And Dan Ares, she know this, and she want to take chair of Westeros. She know it not easy, but I promise her that…and she leave me…”

His features tightened with mingled expressions of pain and anger. He seemed to grow weary of speaking in the Common Tongue and resorted to finishing his speech in Dothraki; pausing only long enough for Jorah to interpret.

“He says it was humiliating to accept her escape and had to appease his angry bloodriders who wanted to go after her head. It was one of the reasons he chose to work with the fat man…Robert Baratheon I’m guessing…when he proposed that they join forces to conquer Westeros and stop Daenerys’s quest. He was only doing it to punish her in kind, for there were many nights he had spent dreaming of her, wondering if she was even still alive and hoping she had made it safe and sound. Perhaps they might have even ruled Westeros together; despite how cursed the Narrow Sea is to his people. He was willing to make that sacrifice.”

When Jorah stopped, Drogo spoke some more and even Jorah seemed to have a bemused yet astonished expression on his visage. Jon was just as flummoxed at this rush of verbal diarrhea. It almost felt as if the khal was desperate to let this burden off him and had finally been given an opportunity to do so.

“He says he knows what a risk it was for Dany to come back and he admires her for it, but a part of him is still angry that she came with you. He wants to punish you both for daring to show your affections for one another in his presence and humiliating him before his khalasar, but he would hate to see the pain in Dany’s eyes if he killed you, which he can do easily if he so chooses. So he is going to make you an offer…since you won the horse race, you will decide what to do with Haggo. The best choice would be to engage him in another duel, but this time, it will be a duel to the death.”

Jon’s breath caught; his eyes widening in disbelief.

“If you are able to defeat him, then he will be willing to give up Dany as well as his quest to conquer Westeros. You still have to prove to be worthy of being her khal, and who knows? You might even end up leaving Vaes Dothrak with your personal khalasar.”

blog.name: bonniegrrl

blog.description: Bonnie Burton is the author of LIVE OR DIE? SURVIVAL HACKS, J.K. ROWLING'S WIZARDING WORLD MOVIE MAGIC AMAZING ARTIFACTS, CRAFTING WITH FEMINISM, THE STAR WARS CRAFT BOOK, DRAW STAR WARS: THE CLONE WARS, GIRLS AGAINST GIRLS and more! Writes for CNET, Inc & Alta California magazine. Find Bonnie on Grrl.com.

summary: Winter stout is coming? HBO releases new Game of Thrones beer Inspired by character Jon Snow, here's hoping Brewery Ommegang's...
caption:
Winter stout is coming? HBO releases new Game of Thrones beer

Inspired by character Jon Snow, here’s hoping Brewery Ommegang’s King in the North beer tastes like victory and not regret.

Read more in my CNET article here.

He loved her
And she loved him 
A true song of Ice and fire❤️
